text: I don't know what's going on with the technology here, but I guess my comment on this would be in general. The Electoral College is fine and my opinion. I don't know all the specifics but I think it's more of the gerrymandering that happens and all the issues of that we talked about before.

Yeah, I also agree that skipping Electoral College seems to be a good thing. I think it makes the candidates kind of a make their views known to more of the state's. 2. The Electoral College makes candidates present their views to more parts of the state.
3. The speaker is afraid that with a national popular vote, candidates would only cater to large cities and areas, not the entire country.

text: Yeah, I also agree this. I believe this is covered in the Constitution. I don't like the idea of just kind of making this up if you were to go this way. text: Yeah, I feel I would actually like to see the 18-year term limits. I think when the lifetime limits were put in place way back in the 1800's life expectancy wasn't expected to be into the 80s and 90s like today and I don't really like the idea of having someone on the Supreme Court for 30 40, even 50 years, I also think would maybe take a little bit of the polarization out of it. If each president were to get to, you wouldn't have some of the games that are being played right now and it's kind of morbid. It feels like they're making current Supreme.
All Arguments Summarized:
1. The person speaking is in favor of 18-year term limits for Supreme Court judges.
2. They believe that when lifetime limits were established in the 1800s, life expectancy was lower than it is today, and having a Supreme Court justice for 30, 40, or even 50 years is not ideal.
3. They argue that term limits would reduce polarization in the Supreme Court.
4. If each president were to appoint two Supreme Court judges during their term, it would prevent the "games" being played in the current system.
5. The speaker finds the current situation, where Supreme Court appointments are influenced by political considerations, to be "morbid."
